number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Dont know what to write here so here is how to install a turbo boost gauge.A little bit of consideration is essential before handing over your cash for a particular boost gauge.First, you need to decide the maximum boost pressure you plan to run. If, for example, you expect to run no more than 1.2 Bar (17.4 psi), a gauge that reads up to 1.5 Bar (21.8 psi) is perfect - it's good to have a little bit of headroom so you can recognise overboost conditions.You may be aware that some boost gauges read positive pressure and engine vacuum; a vacuum scale is very handy for setting up an adjustable blow-off valve, general tuning and faultfinding. Speaking from experience, it's also the easiest way to identify when a small hose has popped off the intake manifold. Certainly, where possible, go for a boost gauge that shows vacuum.Note that the sweep of the needle is important for viewing accuracy - the greater the sweep, the more likely you'll make a correct reading. Another important factor is the diameter of the gauge - the most common diameter is 52mm, but smaller 40mm units can also be bought. Unless mounting space is an issue (which you'll need to determine before making a purchase) we'd opt for the larger size gauge, as they're considerably easier to read.And what's better - a metric or imperial boost gauge? This comes down mainly to personal preference. Psi (pounds per square inch), kilopascals (kPa) and Bar are the most common pressure units - whichever of these suits you is fine.Your budget will determine whether you'll be using a mechanical or, possibly, an electronic boost gauge. Mechanical boost gauges, which use an internal Bourdin tube, can be bought brand new from as little as $40. Electronic boost gauges, however, can run to several hundred dollars. As the name implies, an electronic boost gauge is fed an electrical signal from a remote pressure sensor. Electronic boost gauges have a few advantages - they generally have slightly better accuracy, most have a peak recall function and, because the gauge is fed an electric signal from a remote pressure sensor, there's no requirement to run an air hose into the cabin.Installing a Mechanical Boost GaugeWhere to Find the Optimal Pressure SourceThe best spot to connect a boost gauge is the intake manifold; most typically by 'T-ing' into one of the existing manifold hoses. So why is the intake manifold best, you ask?First, manifold vacuum won't register on boost/vacuum gauges unless you make a connection downstream of the throttle body (ie inside the intake manifold). Only boost pressure can be measured along the path between the turbocharger and throttle body.The second advantage of connecting the boost gauge to the intake manifold is you'll receive a more accurate representation of actual boost - the amount of positive pressure received by the engine. Connecting a boost gauge anywhere between the turbo compressor and throttle will give a too-high boost reading. Thanks to the inevitable restriction through the intercooler core, intercooler plumbing and throttle body, an engine suffers a boost pressure loss on-route to the manifold.Click for larger image Using a 1994 Subaru Impreza WRX as a demo, we T'd our boost gauge (a second-hand Japanese import job) into one of the hose connections on the topside of the manifold. The hose we selected was one that connects to the purge control solenoid on the underside of the manifold.Note that - instead of cutting the factory solenoid hose - we fitted a T-piece to the existing end and added another short length of hose to hook onto the manifold connection. This means, if we later decide to remove the boost gauge, the original hose will be long enough to reattach to the manifold connection. The third port of the T-piece is dedicated to the boost gauge.And what sort of T-pieces should be used? Brass fittings are certainly the most durable but for a completely stealth installation you can't go past the plastic T-pieces used on 993cc Daihatsu Charade carby turbo engines. We're led to believe that the same T-pieces are fitted to atmo versions as well. These beaut little T-pieces can be picked up from the wreckers for free!To ensure none of your boost gauge hoses pop apart, the vacuum hose clamps used on the Daihatsu Charade Turbo are, again, ideal and available for free. We didn't bother with these since we don't expect to run mega boost.Four millimetre rubber vacuum hose - available from auto parts stores for around $3 per metre - is fine for running from the manifold to the in-cabin gauge. Vacuum hose offers OE-level durability and it integrates into the underbonnet scenery perfectly.Routing the HoseThere are a couple of things to remember when routing the hose from the manifold to the in-cabin gauge. The hose should not be kinked, it should be kept well away from intense heat sources and it should not foul the operation of any moving parts - particularly the throttle!We routed our boost gauge hose around the factory blow-off valve tube, beneath the top-mount intercooler, parallel with some factory tubes that run along the firewall and, finally, though the firewall. A couple of cable ties were used to secure the hose into position.Most cars have several firewall openings that are capped with a rubber or plastic seal; we'll use one of these to pass through our boost hose. Have a good look under the bonnet to find a seal that isn't too crowded with wires and/or cables and prise it away from the firewall using a flat-blade screwdriver - be careful not to strain any wires or cables from inside the car. Next, enlarge the hole in the seal so it's big enough to accept the 4mm rubber hose - this can be done with a pair of pointed scissors or a razor. With that done, refit the seal to the firewall and poke the boost hose through to the cabin.Note - in no circumstance should a hose, cable or electrical wire rub against the metal edge of the firewall hole. Install a firewall seal from another vehicle or use a sheath (even just a short length of rubber hose) to avoid contact with that sharp metal edge.Working from the driver's foot well, route the hose beneath the dashboard so it won't foul the operation of the pedals, steering, handbrake or any other controls. Again, use cable ties to secure the hose at various locations to prevent it falling somewhere it shouldn't - like on your feet while driving! Cut the hose in the vicinity where you intend to mount the gauge.Most boost gauges incorporate a bulb for nighttime illumination. Two electrical terminals can usually be found on the back of the gauge - one for a positive electrical feed and one for Earth. Note that - unless LEDs are used for illumination rather than a conventional bulb - you can hook either terminal to the positive or Earth wire. A conventional bulb is not polarity conscious.So where should you wire the illumination bulb to? Well, the best place is to connect into the existing instrument illumination circuit - this enables the boost gauge to illuminate along with the rest of the vehicle's instruments.In the case of this particular install, we powered the boost gauge bulb from the illumination circuit for the cigarette lighter (which is immediately alongside). We simply T'd into the two wires that are used to illuminate the cigarette lighter surround and ran the appropriate length of hook-up wire to the ashtray area. To enable easy installation and future removal, we soldered two short lengths of wire onto the gauge terminals and adjoined the ends with a pair of spade connectors.Note that most (all?) cars' electrical systems will be able to cope with an extra bulb without being overloaded.

												It used to be a pretty good drifting game. It didn't offer much but what it offered was perfectly acceptable considering the price. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												*UPDATE*Okay, so my original impression of this game was extremely positive. Price was low, drifting was actually super fun, and it was a fresh idea. Each update brought something new to the game, and I was genuinely enjoying my time with it. After a few months, they started messing with the handling. This is where it went downhill, in my opinion. At first the handling felt like it had some weight to it, and the controls were smooth. Now it feels like you're driving a piece of paper. Trying to hold a line is insanely aggravating, and turning feels extremely touchy. There's a nice bug where you'll barely tap the brakes and your car goes spinning like crazy. Also, it seems like it's damn near impossible to even go in a straight line anymore, so you're constantly fighting with the touchy steering. I'm sure some people still find this game enjoyable, but for me, that ended when they started messing with the handling. I can't play for more than a few minutes without getting annoyed. It's a bit disappointing really. I had high hopes for this game in the beginning, but unfortunately now I can't recommend it, even for $5.ORIGINAL REVIEWFinally a decent attempt at a drifting game. For $7, it's worth it. Even with only an hour into it, it's been super fun. It definitely has its flaws, as will any new game, but hopefully the developers will continue to work on this because it has potential to be awesome.Wish list:- More vehicles- More exterior customization (wheels, headlights, bumpers, skirts, wings, hoods, etc)- Driver (just a moving steering wheel in an empty seat makes the cockpit view lose immersion)- Better sound (car sounds and music come in and out constantly - had to mute the music for now)- Better control over throttle (in auto shifting, throttle response is laggy)- Better collision affects - maybe add an option to toggle collision with other players- Optimization for higher resolutions - playing in 1440p and have a weird box- Move the point indicator to a different position - definitely gets in the way all the time- The option to host a server and options/rules for that server- Customizable speedo and tach (colors, size, position)A big list, yes, but these are things I would definitely like to see out of a game with potential. I would recommend taking a lot of influence from NFS Underground 2 in regards to customization.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												My honest review of this game. When I first saw this game it was on some youtubers profile, the game looked meh to me. But i'm sceptical about "drift" games (please regard shovelware on android and ios). Then It was featured on steam sales, at full price though. So I decided to check it out.As the trailer started to play the first thing I noticed was the anti lag- rev limiter back fire (machinegun fire). This was the reason that I wanted to give it a try. For 7€. Loads of cars (for a beginning game) Great Icons and lots of tuning options. Engine swaps do fully mean another engine (my V8 240 sx is a beast) Engines are in par with their real life counterparts. This game still needs lots of content, but for 7€ This thing rocks. I love drifting and I drift in every racinggame. Thus to say this is a fun little drift game with loads of updates every few days!-update- Just managed to pull a + 15 000 000 points drift. I'm hapy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												Alright, firstly I bought this game to play with friends. My short description, this game is the worst single-player driving experience ever. There is no good about it, there's no ability to play alone. There's only one option and that's a green "Play" button that takes you to a server list or create your own server with barely any settings to tweak it.I have played a lot of driving games since I've been born with a PS1, arcade, simulation, all the such and playing this game? It's worst than a PS1 driving game. I'd rather play a GameBoy pixel driver game than this. Also, notice how I never said racing, because there is none. Unless you and a friend set up a race on, so far, a count of four tracks that actually connect back to the start. I think there's six tracks in total right now but I'm not willing to play the game without taking a few shots so I barely pay attention to begin with.This game isn't a good drifting experience, it's not a good racing experience, it doesn't even drive right for an arcade title. I would rather spend two dollars at an actual arcade and play Fast and The Furious: Tokyo Drift arcade machine, than playing this. But, and it's a very weak excuse to actual play the game more than I have before, I only enjoy it when I'm playing with a friend or two. That is it, it's barely a good party racer. We laugh at how many bugs are in the game than we actually tandem drift. I'm not willing to list off how many bugs, bad design decisions, let alone how bad of a game it is. How it got on Steam is beyond my knowledge. If I gave this game a score it would be -1/10 it doesn't even compete with arcade racing games from the 90's

Posted: February 3, 2016
												Very nice game love every min of it. If you are into drifting on Carx Drift, Forza Motorsports Or Horizon you will like this. Only complaint is the Deacceleration response is known existent. Would like to see better tire grip physics, and gearing response changes. Right now it feels like every gear is ice with the higher gears being the iciest off limits. The brakes don't feel very confident I find my self guessing if they will do the job or I have to much speed for them to and understeer. The boost effects and engine responses are spot on though. Drifting low power cars feel way more realistic then Horizon or Forza.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND SUPPORTING THIS!!!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												First off, it's one of the only and few car drifting games on Steam. It's also not a garbage can, but it would be nice if it wouldn't freeze randomly during gameplay. The graphics are decent, but some cars need some word in the 3d modeling. Some front bumpers are wider the the fenders at the joinpoints, as if it is a widebody front bumper but noone botherd doing the fenders. Also, if you like tons of power, camber, and antilag backfire at rev limiter, then this game is for you.Here's some pro's and cons:PROS-Inital D (I think?) style graphicsGreat suspension tuning (Offset and Camber)Bad color choice possibilityWell designed tyre/tire smokeMultiplayerLevel EditorCONS-Crashes/Freezes/Stops responding during gameplay randomlyMultiplayer spawn car collidence issuesNo cosmetic modifactions (Other then wheels, and not many at that!)No custom colorsNo bodypanel editing (Removing bumpers, bonnets/hoods, etc.)My overall score would be 7/10. It's a great addition to your collection for 7$/five pounds.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												JDM4iK you really made it, congratulations. I brought this game about a month and a half ago, at first it looked like a game full of potential but with not much to offer. After having a doubt for a day or 2 i finally decided that any game with a decent few cars and a few different maps was worth the small price of 5 pounds. i remember the first time i played it, i must of spent 2 hours on a row in the game, the game was so good and brought back some amazing memories back to when i was building my now 320BHP 180sx. i remember getting 4M drift score and losing it all on a wall cause the brakes where waay too weak. i remember buying that beautiful spirit R as its my dream car, i feel in love with it and since then is my favourite car. I recorded every step of the way, update by update to one day look back to  the beginning of this Amazing game. i knew by the regular updates that by time the game will only get better, but i had no idea it could happen so fast and for that im grateful JDM4iK. Just keep doing what you do and people get ready for the Best Racing game to ever hit pc :D good luck.PS: I can not wait to see them awesome bodykits on my cars and a few new rims. also i think we kinda need more upgrades and being able to tune the car, not big things. only necessaries and basic things that a real drifter would need to drift his car. a 1KBhp would be awesome to have and finally that really needed controller support :D I feel like im writing to Santa here haha but i have faith :D peace Mfukas!!!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												The game has potential, but is not fully complete physics wise.It seems to me, that the tyre grip model has been made in a weird way - The car has to be a certain deg sideways for the wheels to start spinning, when you go straight, the wheels will not spin, even if you clutchkick. When you let go of the throttle, car starts acting very weird and grips instantly, making it nearly impossible to chain different drifts or to end one unless you are living on the handbrake 24/7 (still making it very hard to stop a drift).This is pretty much the only negative side to the game, but has a huge impact on gameplay, really something to be sorted out in the future (i hope so atleast)I really hope developers read this, because this game is unique in a way, just needs to be optimized to fulfill it's goal properly :)

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												So, I recently picked this game up. Purchased it on a whim when it was on sale. And to be honest, it is a lot of fun. The mechanics are a little buggy, and the updates take awhile to come out. But behind that, is a great drifting game. You can throw some of your favorite JDM cars around corners at ridiculous angles. And people are always online (at least in my area), and they are all pretty friendly. Not a whole lot of trolls. I would say, if you want to support the dev (single developer) and be in it for the long haul. This game is worth the purchase. If you don't want to deal with broken states, and buggy updates. This game may not be your cup of tea. I'm looking forward to all that's to come, and will continue to put more hours into this game.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Although I've played this game for only almost an hour, this is my review:It's a "meh" for now but I definitely recommend this game for drift lovers out there. When I first saw the gameplay on Youtube, I insta-bought this game because the price was reasonable with the quality of the game at that time. -The graphics is not great but it isn't that bad in my opinion. -The controls with kb/m is okay but it's quite horrible with a gamepad. In my case, a Wireless Logitech gamepad.-The physics are arcadey, a bit sim, but definitely arcadey. But it's enjoyable and far better than the drifting physics from Grid 2 or Autosport.I haven't tried multiplayer yet but I totally wasn't expecting multiplayer at this early stage of development. Which is good I guess. I did a few setup customizations to my cars but I can't remember what I did exactly or how the customizations was like. I'll get back to this review and edit this post later tonight after I spend some more time with this game.But as of now, I definitely recommend you to buy this game as the price is quite reasonable and the game seems more and more promising after every few updates.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												First and for most this game is worth every penny.Bought this off the back of watching videos of it on youtube. So for £5 thought hey lets try. Read reviews from people playing only 0.1 or 0.2 hours and saying its bad. Far from it.At the time of this review i have played near enough 6 solid hours. And must say im still loving it! I would say a good hour is needed into the game to get some upgrades and learn the handling to make it more fun! Ive played many driving games over the years and modded games to enable drifting. But for once to jump straight into a drift game is nice.Pro's: Good selection of cars (so far)Good tuning optionsCar graphic quality TURBO FLUTTEREase of earning moneyCon's:Some maps can be a bit glitchyLoose points from hitting bumps every so slightly (would like to see improved)Aside that its a £5 drifting game! Cant expect loads from it! Hope the work and updates continue as they have and look forward to the future!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												I absolutely love this game. Sure it's got it's pro's and con's, but in my opinion, the vast amount of different ways you can tune your cars settings weighs out the con's. People who gave this game a negative review likely didn't play it long enough to understand the game, and actually think on how they can make the game be fun for them.I love all of the tune settings, not the upgrades, but the tiny changes you can make to your wheels, grip settings, drive load options (4WD / RWD / FWD / etc). Each settings literally plays a large role in how your car handles, you can't create a "perfect setup". Because every setup has its flaws because that's just how things roll, you can however master your setup to allow your car to drift the way you want it to. Whether realistic drift (which I prefer) or ice drifting for Tandems.(All my opinions, I've got a pretty fair amount of hours within the game, and knowledge about things under the hood of the game.)Pros:Fair amount of car optionsEach setting when Tuning your car plays a noticeable roleMore than fair amount of players still playingVery mature players, hardly any xbox kidsFriendly community, Drag Race events, Drift races, Tandems, etc.only 5$, like seriously. It's just 5$.Nice looking bodykits for certain carsAbility to create your own mapsAbility to use modded vehicles and maps (modded vehicles as in vehicles created or imported by other players)Fair racing wheel support (Logitech G27 is the most popular and best working apprently)Large community within ForumsGAME IS NOT ABANDONED (DEVELOPER IS ON A VACATION TRIP, CHILL OUT PEEPS)Fair amount of maps to choose fromEasy to use hotkeys (Reset Key, Autosteering Toggle, Repair Vehicle, etc)Tofu Hachi Roku (puts on shades)Auto Countersteering can be disabled through recent updates (THANK GOD)Collision is Disabled (Helps prevent pesky trolls from messing up your sick driftz)Cons:Physics can be wonkey when hitting walls at certain anglesMoney can be fairly hard to earn by purely drifting alone (Which most people end up Registry editing their money and then claim they drifted all of it)Small amount of body kits and style features for small number of cars.Engine sounds can get a little tedious to listen to (especially if you're redlining the absolute F*CK OUT OF IT FOR THAT SICK DRIFT)Akina map is very rough and can't be properly drifted on at highspeeds, or even medium speeds :(Few rim stylesVery basic colors to choose from for rims and the car body (would love to be able to put Vinyl designs)

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												It looks amazing, great sounds tracks, but the gameplay is not even close to feeling finished. It is boring just because there  is nothing to do but play like 5 really basic maps and everything feels extremely slow.I like the fact that it is difficult just because it gives you something to practice but what is the point of practicing if there is a glitch that gives you infinite money and unlock everything instantly. You "Beat" the game unlockable wise in just 3 minutes. Customizability is amazing but yet again unfinished. The parts to the cars are amazing, but sadly there are only body kits for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cars.Overall I would not buy this game unless it was ~$5UPDATE: It seems JDM4IK is SLOWLY updating this game but i assume that is because he has a lot on his hands. I still reccomend the game if you are into good looking drifting games with difficult physics. Also i have discovered the forum pages with many car mods so a good community is always a bonus. I changed my review to a thumbs up for these reasons.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Not in any shape or form is this the best out there. The handling is shoddy and there's no definitive controller support, and a whole lot of content in the game.Now, in the 4 hours I've put into this game, I loved it. This game has loads of potential. It has a decent selection of vehicles and engines you can put into them for where the game is at development wise, and they recently started adding bodykits to cars (only 2 cars have them so far). My biggest pet peeve of mine is the handling. It's almost as if you're on ice. That, along with no guarunteed controller support and no clutch, is the only things I find wrong with it right now.Is it worth the $7? Maybe not. Maybe it is, since new content is being added with almost every update.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Ok. Let's start off with the cons:-Cannot play low-res fullscreen or the fittment doesn't work.-Primitive graphics options, can't lower texture details and model quality etc.-Terrible controller support.-Lag for days.-Can't look backwards.-Not every car has bodykits.-Can't shift into neutral and do backfiring.Now, the pros:+Great graphics.+Cars drift amazing with the keyboard.+Tuning aspect of the game is amazing.+Turbo spooling and BOV are freakin' crazy. Nobody has ever had such audio.+Really immersive.+Multiplayer.+Tandems.+Track editors.+Manual gearbox.Bottom line. Game has pretty noticable flaws which made me want to get a refund, but, after that I learned to appreciate the good things and ignore the bad ones. Remember, the game didn't really have a big budget at the start. I say it was worth the 7 euros.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I know I don't have much hours on this game but I would like the write a review. First of all, you get what you pay for with this game (physics wise). The physics with drifting are very annoying especially since there is no controller support yet, you  don't feel confident as you enter a drift and it always tries to snap you the other way. It is quite annoying and on maps with long, swinging corners this isn't ideal. That being said, this game is only 7 dollars and you get a lot for what you pay for, there is upwards of 10 cars that you can modify to your liking. They have camber and wheel spacing as well as a bunch of colors for the body and wheels. You are also able to do mad engine swaps, for example I have a fully built 2jz that has about 700 bhp plus nitrous. You are able to choose headers, turbos, nitrous, ecu, exhaust, and much more. There is even multiplayer to play with other people or friends. Though the multiplayer is laggy since there is only one server you can't really risk more than a 2 person tandem since the car movements update every few seconds. It is very choppy and most people run into you and make you flip over. Overall, this game has very little flaws (the flaws though are big ones) minus the buggy multiplayer, and physics of the car there are a lot of veriety in cars and upgrades. If the developer changed some of the physics to not be as annoying and better multiplayer, they could easily sell this game for another 10 dollars more. Overall it gives you alot for a game that only costs 7 dollars. But, don't complain to much because you have to remember this is a new indie game and there are many bugs still being worked out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Although I've played this game for only almost an hour, this is my review:It's a "meh" for now but I definitely recommend this game for drift lovers out there. When I first saw the gameplay on Youtube, I insta-bought this game because the price was reasonable with the quality of the game at that time. -The graphics is not great but it isn't that bad in my opinion. -The controls with kb/m is okay but it's quite horrible with a gamepad. In my case, a Wireless Logitech gamepad.-The physics are arcadey, a bit sim, but definitely arcadey. But it's enjoyable and far better than the drifting physics from Grid 2 or Autosport.I haven't tried multiplayer yet but I totally wasn't expecting multiplayer at this early stage of development. Which is good I guess. I did a few setup customizations to my cars but I can't remember what I did exactly or how the customizations was like. I'll get back to this review and edit this post later tonight after I spend some more time with this game.But as of now, I definitely recommend you to buy this game as the price is quite reasonable and the game seems more and more promising after every few updates.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												Well where do I start. It's a game about drifting and it doesn't even have controller support. I mean, yes you can plug in your controller and try to use it, but the controls are terrible (auto-throttle that doesn't even work properly, some controls are completely missing etc), and the keyboard controls are near impossible to use. The physics are just completely terrible. You spin out every 2 seconds, and if you go off the gas you just lose your drift completely. You wanna use the brake? Free flight to mars. Most of the stuff in the game is ripped off from somewhere else (an entire track for example). If you want some fun drifting on pc, please don't buy this game, there are way better variants like rFactor, Asetto Corsa, Live For Speed. This game did not bring me a single bit of fun, all it did is frustrate me. I spent more time in the ingame overlay trying to figure out how to fix the game, than actually playing it. The only thing that is barely acceptable is the Car customization (body mods for 3 different cars. wow!). It feels like I've been scammed (thank god for refunds). I give this a 2/10 because at least they tried...... and still did a bad job.

												This game is absolute trash. Out of the box the game is unpolished and laggy to inputs, keyboard controls are among the worst out there, and the physics were made by a five year old. Oh, and controller support is essentially non exsistent. Everytime you tail tap a wall, you are instantly 360'd and your multiplier is lost, braking will turn into reverse long before the car has actually stopped. The only good thing about this game is the fact the cars look pretty, thats about it. Do not buy this game, you will regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												My honest review of this game. When I first saw this game it was on some youtubers profile, the game looked meh to me. But i'm sceptical about "drift" games (please regard shovelware on android and ios). Then It was featured on steam sales, at full price though. So I decided to check it out.As the trailer started to play the first thing I noticed was the anti lag- rev limiter back fire (machinegun fire). This was the reason that I wanted to give it a try. For 7€. Loads of cars (for a beginning game) Great Icons and lots of tuning options. Engine swaps do fully mean another engine (my V8 240 sx is a beast) Engines are in par with their real life counterparts. This game still needs lots of content, but for 7€ This thing rocks. I love drifting and I drift in every racinggame. Thus to say this is a fun little drift game with loads of updates every few days!-update- Just managed to pull a + 15 000 000 points drift. I'm hapy.
